nodes.text: Contact comfort, more than nursing or food-provision, is the primary variable driving the development and persistence of infant macaque affection for the mother or mother surrogate

Method: Constructed two mother surrogates for neonatal macaques: a soft, warm cloth-covered surrogate that provided contact comfort and a wire-mesh surrogate that provided nursing and postural support but minimal contact comfort

Method: Dual-mother experiment: infants raised with both a cloth and a wire surrogate in attached cubicles; for half the infants the cloth lactated and for half the wire lactated; time spent on each surrogate was automatically recorded beginning in the first days of life

Method: Multiple behavioral tests to assess affection and security: fear stimuli tests, open-field tests, modified Butler box visual exploration test, retention tests after separation, puzzle-unlocking tests, and control groups including late-introduced mothers and motherless controls
Result: Infants strongly preferred the cloth surrogate over the wire surrogate regardless of which surrogate provided milk
Evidence: Time-on-mother recordings during first 165 days showed overwhelming preference for cloth mother and negligible importance of lactation in determining contact time
Result: Single-surrogate controls (wire-only vs cloth-only) showed no difference in milk intake or weight gain, but wire-reared infants had softer stools suggesting psychosomatic effects
Result: In fear-producing situations infants consistently sought the cloth mother surrogate as a haven of safety regardless of which surrogate lactated
Result: In open-field tests infants used the cloth mother as a secure base for exploration and showed reduced emotionality scores when the cloth mother was present

Result: Modified Butler box visual exploration tests showed infants responded frequently to cloth mother and conspecific infant stimuli but not to wire mother or empty box, independent of which surrogate lactated

Result: Affectional retention tests after separation showed long-lasting preference and resistance to extinction for the cloth mother across many months and measures including modified Butler box, open-field reunion, and puzzle-unlocking tasks

Evidence: Control infants introduced to cloth and wire mothers at 250 days initially showed fear and avoidance but within days adopted strong contact behavior with cloth mothers, indicating capacity for later acquisition though intensity is reduced relative to early-reared infants

Conclusion: Contact comfort is a fundamental affectional variable in infant macaques that overrides nursing as the basis for attachment, provides security and a base for exploration, and produces long-term, resistant bonds
Claim: Nursing's primary affectional function may be to provide increased body contact frequency rather than to condition affection via drive reduction

Limitation: Findings derive from rhesus macaque infants and artificial surrogate designs; variables such as postural support, rocking, maternal sounds, visual features, and the real mother's role require further experimental analysis
